![](_page_0_Picture_0.jpeg) # **AREAS RELATED TO CIRCLES** ## **11.1 Areas of Sector and Segment of a Circle** You have already come across the terms *sector* and *segment* of a circle in your earlier classes. Recall that the portion (or part) of the circular region enclosed by two radii and the corresponding arc is called a *sector* of the circle and the portion (or part) of the circular region enclosed between a chord and the corresponding arc is called a *segment* of the circle. Thus, in Fig. 11.1, shaded region OAPB is a *sector* of the circle with centre O. ∠ AOB is called the *angle* of the sector. Note that in this figure, unshaded region OAQB is also a sector of the circle. For obvious reasons, OAPB is called the *minor sector* and OAQB is called the *major sector*. You can also see that angle of the major sector is 360° – ∠ AOB. Now, look at Fig. 11.2 in which AB is a chord of the circle with centre O. So, shaded region APB is a segment of the circle. You can also note that unshaded region AQB is another segment of the circle formed by the chord AB. For obvious reasons, APB is called the *minor segment* and AQB is called the *major segment*. **Remark :** When we write 'segment' and 'sector' we will mean the 'minor segment' and the 'minor sector' respectively, unless stated otherwise. ![](_page_0_Figure_7.jpeg) **11** ![](_page_0_Figure_8.jpeg) ![](_page_0_Picture_9.jpeg) #### AREAS RELATED TO CIRCLES 155 Now with this knowledge, let us try to find some relations (or formulae) to calculate their areas. Let OAPB be a sector of a circle with centre O and radius *r* (see Fig. 11.3). Let the degree measure of Ð AOB be q. You know that area of a circle (in fact of a circular region or disc) is p*r* 2 . In a way, we can consider this circular region to be a sector forming an angle of 360° (i.e., of degree measure 360) at the centre O. Now by applying the Unitary Method, we can arrive at the area of the sector OAPB as follows: ![](_page_1_Figure_5.jpeg) When degree measure of the angle at the centre is 360, area of the sector = p*r* 2 So, when the degree measure of the angle at the centre is 1, area of the sector = 2 *r* Therefore, when the degree measure of the angle at the centre is q, area of the $$ sector = \frac{\pi r^2}{360} \times \theta = \frac{\theta}{360} \times \pi r^2. $$ 360 Thus, we obtain the following relation (or formula) for area of a sector of a circle: Area of the sector of angle $$ \theta = \frac{\theta}{360} \times \pi r^2 $$ , where *r* is the radius of the circle and q the angle of the sector in degrees. Now, a natural question arises : Can we find the length of the arc APB corresponding to this sector? Yes. Again, by applying the Unitary Method and taking the whole length of the circle (of angle 360°) as 2p*r*, we can obtain the required length of the arc APB as $$ \frac{\theta}{360} \times 2\pi r $$ . So, **length of an arc of a sector of angle** q **= 2 360** *r* . ![](_page_1_Figure_16.jpeg) Now let us take the case of the area of the segment APB of a circle with centre O and radius *r* (see Fig. 11.4). You can see that : Area of the segment APB = Area of the sector OAPB – Area of OAB $$ = \frac{\theta}{360} \times \pi r^2 - \text{area of } \Delta \text{OAB} $$ **Note :** From Fig. 11.3 and Fig. 11.4 respectively, you can observe that: Area of the major sector OAQB = *r*2 – Area of the minor sector OAPB and Area of major segment AQB = *r*2 – Area of the minor segment APB Let us now take some examples to understand these concepts (or results). ![](_page_2_Figure_6.jpeg) Area of the corresponding major sector $$ = \pi r^2 - \text{area of sector OAPB} $$ = (3.14 × 16 – 4.19) cm2 = 46.05 cm2 = 46.1 cm2(approx.) **Alternatively,** area of the major sector = 2 (360 – ) 360 *r* $$ = \left(\frac{360 - 30}{360}\right) \times 3.14 \times 16 \text{ cm}^2 $$ $$ = \frac{330}{360} \times 3.14 \times 16 \text{ cm}^2 = 46.05 \text{ cm}^2 $$ $$ = 46.1 \text{ cm}^2 \text{ (approx.)} $$ **Example 2 :** Find the area of the segment AYB shown in Fig. 11.6, if radius of the circle is 21 cm and $$ \angle $$ AOB = 120°. (Use $\pi = \frac{22}{7}$ ) ![](_page_3_Figure_3.jpeg) **Solution :** Area of the segment AYB = Area of sector OAYB – Area of OAB (1) Now, area of the sector OAYB = $$ \frac{120}{360} \times \frac{22}{7} \times 21 \times 21 \text{ cm}^2 = 462 \text{ cm}^2 $$ (2) For finding the area of OAB, draw OM AB as shown in Fig. 11.7. Find **Fig. 11.8** ![](_page_4_Figure_19.jpeg) (i) the area of that part of the field in which the horse can graze. (ii) the increase in the grazing area if the rope were 10 m long instead of 5 m. (Use = 3.14) - **9.** A brooch is made with silver wire in the form of a circle with diameter 35 mm. The wire is also used in making 5 diameters which divide the circle into 10 equal sectors as shown in Fig. 11.9. Find : - (i) the total length of the silver wire required. - (ii) the area of each sector of the brooch. - **10.** An umbrella has 8 ribs which are equally spaced (see Fig. 11.10). Assuming umbrella to be a flat circle of radius 45 cm, find the area between the two consecutive ribs of the umbrella. - **11.** A car has two wipers which do not overlap. Find the total area cleaned at each sweep of the blades. - **12.** To warn ships for underwater rocks, a lighthouse spreads a red coloured light over a sector of angle 80° to a distance of 16.5 km. Find the area of the sea over which the ships are warned. (Use = 3.14) - **13.** A round table cover has six equal designs as shown in Fig. 11.11. If the radius of the cover is 28 cm, find the cost of making the designs at the rate of ` 0.35 per cm2 . (Use 3 = 1.7) - **14.** Tick the correct answer in the following : Area of a sector of angle *p* (in degrees) of a circle with radius R is ![](_page_5_Figure_11.jpeg) $$ \Delta $$ **Fig. 11.9** **Fig. 11.10** ![](_page_5_Picture_14.jpeg) **Fig. 11.11** ## **11.2 Summary** In this chapter, you have studied the following points : **1.** Length of an arc of a sector of a circle with radius *r* and angle with degree measure is $$ \frac{\theta}{360} \times 2\pi r. $$ - **2.** Area of a sector of a circle with radius *r* and angle with degree measure is 2 360 *r* - **3.** Area of segment of a circle - = Area of the corresponding sector Area of the corresponding triangle.

images.description: This diagram shows a circle with center O and a chord AP that divides the circle into two segments. The smaller shaded region is labeled "Minor Segment" and the larger unshaded region is labeled "Major Segment," illustrating how a chord creates these two distinct parts of a circle.

images.name: _page_0_Picture_9.jpeg
images.description: This image shows Fig. 11.2, which illustrates a circle with center O and a chord AB that divides the circle into two segments. The diagram demonstrates the concept of minor and major segments, where the shaded region APB represents the minor segment and the unshaded region AQB represents the major segment formed by the chord AB.

The figure illustrates the geometric setup used to derive the formula for calculating the area of a sector in terms of the central angle and radius.

images.name: _page_1_Figure_16.jpeg
images.description: This diagram shows a circle with center O and two radii OA and OB forming a sector, with a chord AB creating a segment (the shaded region between the chord and arc). The diagram illustrates the geometric components needed to calculate the area of a circular segment, which equals the sector area minus the triangular area OAB.

exercises.question: Find the area of a sector of a circle with radius 6 cm if angle of the sector is 60°.
Find the area of a quadrant of a circle whose circumference is 22 cm.
exercises.answer: First find the radius: Circumference = 2πr, so 22 = 2 × (22/7) × r, which gives r = 3.5 cm. A quadrant has angle 90°. Area of quadrant = (90/360) × πr² = (1/4) × (22/7) × (3.5)² = (1/4) × (22/7) × 12.25 = 9.625 cm²

exercises.question: The length of the minute hand of a clock is 14 cm. Find the area swept by the minute hand in 5 minutes.
exercises.answer: In 5 minutes, the minute hand moves through (5/60) × 360° = 30°. Using the sector area formula: Area = (θ/360) × πr² = (30/360) × (22/7) × 14² = (1/12) × (22/7) × 196 = (22 × 196)/(7 × 12) = 4312/84 ≈ 51.33 cm²

exercises.question: A chord of a circle of radius 10 cm subtends a right angle at the centre. Find the area of the corresponding: (i) minor segment (ii) major sector. (Use π = 3.14)
exercises.answer: (i) Minor segment area = Area of sector - Area of triangle. Sector area = (90/360) × 3.14 × 10² = 78.5 cm². Triangle area = (1/2) × 10 × 10 × sin(90°) = 50 cm². Minor segment = 78.5 - 50 = 28.5 cm². (ii) Major sector = Total circle area - Minor sector = 3.14 × 100 - 78.5 = 314 - 78.5 = 235.5 cm²

exercises.question: In a circle of radius 21 cm, an arc subtends an angle of 60° at the centre. Find: (i) the length of the arc (ii) area of the sector formed by the arc (iii) area of the segment formed by the corresponding chord
A chord of a circle of radius 15 cm subtends an angle of 60° at the centre. Find the areas of the corresponding minor and major segments of the circle. (Use π = 3.14 and √3 = 1.73)
exercises.answer: Sector area = (60/360) × 3.14 × 15² = 117.75 cm². Triangle area = (1/2) × 15² × sin(60°) = (1/2) × 225 × 1.73/2 = 97.31 cm². Minor segment = 117.75 - 97.31 = 20.44 cm². Major segment = Total circle area - Minor segment = 3.14 × 225 - 20.44 = 706.5 - 20.44 = 686.06 cm²

exercises.question: A chord of a circle of radius 12 cm subtends an angle of 120° at the centre. Find the area of the corresponding segment of the circle. (Use π = 3.14 and √3 = 1.73)

A horse is tied to a peg at one corner of a square shaped grass field of side 15 m by means of a 5 m long rope. Find (i) the area of that part of the field in which the horse can graze. (ii) the increase in the grazing area if the rope were 10 m long instead of 5 m. (Use π = 3.14)
exercises.answer: (i) The horse can graze in a quarter circle of radius 5 m. Area = (1/4) × 3.14 × 5² = 19.625 m². (ii) With 10 m rope, area = (1/4) × 3.14 × 10² = 78.5 m². Increase = 78.5 - 19.625 = 58.875 m²

exercises.question: A brooch is made with silver wire in the form of a circle with diameter 35 mm. The wire is also used in making 5 diameters which divide the circle into 10 equal sectors. Find: (i) the total length of the silver wire required. (ii) the area of each sector of the brooch.
An umbrella has 8 ribs which are equally spaced. Assuming umbrella to be a flat circle of radius 45 cm, find the area between the two consecutive ribs of the umbrella.
exercises.answer: Each sector between consecutive ribs has angle 360°/8 = 45°. Area of each sector = (45/360) × (22/7) × 45² = (1/8) × (22/7) × 2025 = 795.54 cm²

exercises.question: A car has two wipers which do not overlap. Each wiper has a blade of length 25 cm sweeping through an angle of 115°. Find the total area cleaned at each sweep of the blades.
exercises.answer: Area cleaned by one wiper = (115/360) × (22/7) × 25² = (115/360) × (22/7) × 625. Area = 625.87 cm². Total area by both wipers = 2 × 625.87 = 1251.74 cm²

exercises.question: To warn ships for underwater rocks, a lighthouse spreads a red coloured light over a sector of angle 80° to a distance of 16.5 km. Find the area of the sea over which the ships are warned. (Use π = 3.14)
A round table cover has six equal designs as shown in Fig. 11.11. If the radius of the cover is 28 cm, find the cost of making the designs at the rate of ₹ 0.35 per cm². (Use √3 = 1.7)
exercises.answer: Each design is a sector with angle 60°. Area of one design = (60/360) × (22/7) × 28² = (1/6) × (22/7) × 784 = 410.67 cm². Total area of 6 designs = 6 × 410.67 = 2464 cm². Cost = 2464 × 0.35 = ₹ 862.40

exercises.question: Tick the correct answer: Area of a sector of angle p (in degrees) of a circle with radius R is
exercises.answer: The correct formula for the area of a sector is (p/360) × πR², where p is the angle in degrees and R is the radius. This follows from the proportion that the sector area bears to the total circle area, which is the same as the proportion of the sector angle to 360°.

summary.title: Areas Related to Circles
key_concepts: Area of a sector = (θ/360) × πr², where θ is in degrees
Area of a segment = Area of sector - Area of triangle
Minor and major sectors/segments based on angle being less than or greater than 180°
Applications of sector and segment formulas in real-world problems
summary.summary: This chapter focuses on calculating areas and arc lengths related to circles, specifically sectors and segments. A sector is the region between two radii and an arc, while a segment is the region between a chord and an arc. The chapter provides formulas for calculating the area of sectors using the proportion method, where the sector area relates to the total circle area as the sector angle relates to 360°. It also covers finding arc lengths and segment areas by subtracting the triangular portion from the sector area. The concepts are applied to various practical problems involving clocks, grazing areas, wipers, and other real-world scenarios.
